results.title: Stress and you: learning to cope (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Herbert Long and Neil Mawby Productions
results.brief_description: Recognition of stress as a health problem stemming from emotional or environmental pressures. Suggests ways of dealing with stressful situations, including a stress-reducing daily routine designed to avoid potential stress situations.

results.title: Streetlife
results.creator_credit: Image Link and Business Victoria: Dept of State Development
results.brief_description: Four programs examine ways small communities have created employment. Program 1: Profiles the Beechworth Bakery as an example of a booming small business and tries to identify the factors which have made it successful. Program 2: Examines ecotourism in Kaikoura, New Zealand where the recognition of a natural feature has turned the town economy around. Program 3: Overviews Ouyen’s signage and streetscape projects which put the town on the tourist map. Program 4: Highlights Oamaru, New Zealand where the conservation of heritage buidings provided employment and attracted tourist dollars.

results.title: Stranger's kiss
results.creator_credit: Matthew Chapman, Douglas Dilge and Kill Productions
results.brief_description: Hollywood, 1955, and independent film director Stanley (Peter Coyote) is eking out production day by day on a film financed by gangster Frank Silva, and starring Silva’s girlfriend, Carol (Victoria Tennant) as the leading lady, Betty. Stanley’s film is a love story about a boxer, a gangster, and a girl, and in a case of life imitating art, the leading actor (Blaine Novak) falls in love with Carol/Betty, unbeknownst that she already has a boyfriend who also happens to he a vicious gangster and the financer of the film. This film about a film is supposedly a fictionalised account on what went on behind the production of Kubrick’s “Killer’s kiss”, and has earned comparisons to a later production - Woody Allen’s “Bullets over Broadway” (1994). Cast also includes Richard Romanus and Dan Shor.

results.title: Strange cities
results.brief_description: ‘Strange cities’ is an experimental interactive multimedia work that tells of the survival of the Russian and Chinese Communist Revolutions by two Russian exiles. It draws upon the legacy of the Shanghai milieu, the Chinese gangster film, a musical cabaret genre, orientalist erotic literature, intrigue novels, and the films of Josef von Sternberg to explore memory, transience and the urban imagination. It is an experimental interactive multimedia work authored for CD-Rom release and exhibition. Through the disclosure of evidence, Sasha dreams, discovers, remembers the exilic identity of her grandparents Xenia and Sergei Ermolaeff (a composer and orchestra leader) in fragments and traces of their music, memories, personal effects and photographs, in their struggle to survive the Russian and Chinese Communist Revolutions. The inspiration for the work is a tune of the same name - a musical illustration, an imaginary vision of old Shanghai, Chinese metropolis, and International Settlement, conjuring mythic, filmic, musical and personal images of the city port. The ‘Strange cities’ musical score1 written by Alexander Vertinsky, Serge Ermoll and Ira Bloch, was first performed by a jazz orchestra of White Russian emigres in the cabarets of the International Settlement of Shanghai, China in the 1930’s and 40’s. ‘Strange cities’ draws upon the legacy of the Shanghai milieu, the Chinese gangster film, a musical cabaret genre, orientalist erotic literature, intrigue novels, and the films of Josef von Sternberg. Coined capital of the international underworld, the city of Shanghai became a seductively strange locale symbolized in the Western imagination, in reality the city was most often the final port of call for political refugees.

results.title: Str8 outta Melbourne
results.brief_description:
Iconic images of Melbourne city flash on and off the screen to the beat of the boys from the burbs, rap performers, Jesse Galofaro and Somchay Phakonkham.
Contains two versions: 00:14-03:51 - unedited and uses coarse language 03:58-07:40 - edited (no coarse language)

results.title: Story of a book
results.brief_description: This program follows author Holling C. Holling through the process of creating “Pagoo”, the story of a hermit crab. Relates the steps involved in writing a book: the birth of an idea, doing the research, writing and rewriting, illustrating and printing. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Storm of fire: World War II and the destruction of Dresden
results.brief_description: Presents a compelling documentary of the historical events that led to and included the destruction of Dresden, Germany, in February 1945. The events of the war between Germany and the Allies are followed from the early days of German victories to the eve of the bombing. The film shows the total devastation of Germany’s morale and strength. It is comprised of the actual sights and sounds of the events taken from archive footage and recordings. The culminating destruction is one of history’s terrible commentaries of the consequences and tragedy of total war.

results.title: Stop the red steer
results.brief_description: Shows the devastation of areas near Hobart in the February 1967 bushfires and the efforts of regular and volunteer firefighters to control them. Demonstrates methods generally recommended for preventing and dealing with bushfires.

results.title: Stop the drop: a concert for nuclear disarmament
results.brief_description: Footage from a benefit rock concert for the anti-uranium movement is shown and is combined with interviews with the performers of the concert. The concert was held at the Sidney Myer Music Bowl in Melbourne and the performers included bands such as “Goanna”, “Midnight Oil” “INXS”, “Men at work” and “Redgum”.
